sentence-detokenized: The EU rejects a German call to boycott British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRUSSELS 1996-08-22
The European Commission said on Thursday it disagrees with German advice to consumers to avoid British lamb until scientists determine whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.

Germany's representative on the European Union's veterinary committee, Werner Zwingmann, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy sheep meat from countries other than Britain until the scientific advice is clearer.
"We do not support any such recommendation because we see no grounds for it," the Commission's chief spokesman Nikolaus van der Pas told a press briefing.
He said that further scientific study was needed and if it was found that action was needed, the European Union should take it.

Last month's proposal by EU Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler to ban the use of sheep brain, spleen and spinal cord in the human and animal food chain was a very specific and precautionary step to protect human health, he said.
Fischler proposed Europe-wide measures following reports from the UK and France that sheep can contract bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) - mad cow disease - in laboratory conditions.

However, Fischler agreed to reconsider his proposal after the EU's Standing Veterinary Committee, the national animal health official, questioned the validity of such a measure, saying there was little risk to human health.
Earlier, at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers, Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio accused Fischler of raising unjustified alarm by "dangerous generalisations".
Only France and the UK supported Fischler's proposal.
EU veterinary scientific and multidisciplinary committees are due to re-examine the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
Sheep have long been known to contract scrapie, a brain-damaging disease similar to BSE, which is thought to have been transmitted to cattle through feed containing animal waste.

British farmers denied on Thursday that their sheep posed any danger to human health, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could affect consumers across Europe.
"We need to be very wary of how other countries are going to take up the German example," John Lloyd Jones, president of the National Farmers Union of Wales (NFU), told BBC radio.

Bonn has led efforts to protect public health after consumer confidence collapsed in March after a British report suggested that people could contract a disease similar to mad cow disease by eating contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47 600 sheep from Britain last year, almost half of the total.
It imported 4 275 tonnes of British mutton, representing around 10% of total imports.
A rare draft of a Hendrix song sells for nearly $17,000.
A rare handwritten sketch of a song by American guitar legend Jimi Hendrix sold for nearly $17,000 on Thursday at an auction of the late musician's favourite things.
The Florida restaurant paid £10,925 ($16,935) for a draft of the song "Ain't No Telling," which Hendrix wrote in late 1966 on London hotel stationery.
At the end of a concert in January 1967 in Nottingham, England, he threw a sheet of paper into the audience, where it was retrieved by a fan.
Buyers were also interested in 16 other items put up for auction by Hendrix's ex-girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, who lived with him from 1966 to 1969.
It included a black lacquered and bead-lined box that Hendrix used to store his drugs, which an anonymous Australian buyer purchased for £5,060 ($7,845).
The guitarist died in 1970 of a drug overdose at the age of 27.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the atmosphere for talks.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China on Thursday accused Taipei of spoiling the atmosphere for renewed cross-Strait talks with a visit by Taiwanese Vice President Lien Chan to Ukraine this week that infuriated Beijing.

Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Kuofang said just hours after Chinese state media reported that the time had come to start political talks with Taiwan: "The atmosphere needed to start the talks has been disrupted by Taiwanese authorities."
State media quoted China's chief negotiator with Taipei, Tang Shubei, as telling a group of visitors from Taiwan on Wednesday that the time had come for the rivals to hold political talks.
"Now is the time for both sides to start political talks...
is to end the state of hostilities," Thursday's People's Daily quoted Tang as saying.

In an interview with Reuters television, Shen of the Foreign Ministry said he had read reports of Tang's comments but gave no details on why the negotiator considered it time for talks with Taiwan, which Beijing regards as a renegade province.
China, which has long opposed all of Taipei's efforts to gain greater international recognition, was angered this week by Taiwanese Vice President Lien's visit to Ukraine.
China says the time has come to negotiate on Taiwan.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China has said the time has come for political negotiations with Taiwan and that the rival island should take practical steps to achieve that goal.

Late on Wednesday evening, the official Xinhua news agency quoted Tang Shubei, executive vice chairman of the Cross-Strait Relations Association, as saying that consultations would be held to determine the time and format of the talks.
German July car registrations rose 14.2 percentage points year-on-year.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
Germany's first motor vehicle registrations in July this year were up 14.2% compared with a year earlier, the Federal Motor Vehicle Authority said on Thursday.
The Bureau reported that 356,725 new cars were registered in July 1996 - 304,850 cars and 15,613 trucks.
These figures represent a 13.6 per cent increase for cars and a 2.2 per cent decrease for trucks compared to July 1995.
The number of motorcycle registrations increased by 32.7% in this period.
The growth was partly due to an increased number of Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers said domestic demand was weak, the federal office said.
Almost all German carmakers saw an increase in registrations in this period.
Volkswagen AG received 77,719 registrations, slightly more than a quarter of the total.
Opel AG and General Motors came second with 49,269 registrations, 16.4% of the total.
Ford was third with 35,563 registrations, up 11.7%.
Only Seat and Porsche recorded fewer registrations in July 1996 compared to July last year.
Seat recorded 3,420 registrations compared to 5,522 registrations in July of the previous year.
The number of Porsche registrations fell from 643 to 554.
THE GREEK SOCIALISTS GIVE THE PRIME MINISTER THE GREEN LIGHT FOR ELECTIONS.

The executive presidency of the Greek Socialist Party has given the green light to Prime Minister Costas Simitis to call early elections, the party's secretary-general Costas Skandalidis told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make an official announcement after a cabinet meeting later on Thursday, Skandalidis said.
-- Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4

Israel eases fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said on Thursday that the current tensions between the two countries appear to be a storm in a glass of water.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israel's ambassador in Washington led the failed negotiations with Syria, told Israel Radio that it looks like Damascus wants to talk rather than fight.
"It seems to me that {(1)[MISC's] Syrian priority} is still negotiations.
The Syrians are confused, they're certainly tense, but the general assessment here in Washington is that it's basically a storm in a glass of water," he said.
Rabinovic ends his term as ambassador.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elissar, a former Israeli envoy to Egypt and politician from the right-wing Likud party.
On Wednesday, Israel sent a message to Syria via Washington saying it was committed to peace and wanted to start negotiations without preconditions.
However, she said she believed Damascus had created a dangerous atmosphere.
Syria on Wednesday accused Israel of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently test-fired a missile.
It stated that its arms purchases were for defence purposes.

"The message we sent (Syrian President Hafiz al-Assad) is that Israel is ready to start peace negotiations at any time without preconditions," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy said in an interview with Israel Radio.
Tensions have been escalating since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June, when he promised to keep the Golan Heights, which Israel won from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
Israeli-Syrian peace talks on the Golan have been deadlocked since 1991, despite the previous government's willingness to make concessions on the Golan.
Peace talks between the two sides were last held in February.
"The voices coming out of Damascus are bad, not good.
Media...
are full of expressions and statements that must be disturbing...
This artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can become its prisoners," Levy said.
"We expect Syria, if its face is turned towards peace, to respond to Israel's message to start peace negotiations, because that is our goal," he said. "
We don't want war, God forbid.
No one benefits from wars. "
Israel's Channel Two television said Damascus had sent a "reassuring signal" to Israel.
It did not cite any source for this report.
Spokesmen for Netanyahu and Levy said they could not confirm this.
The television also said Netanyahu sent messages to calm Syria through Cairo, the United States and Moscow.
A Polish diplomat denies that nurses are stranded in Libya.
TUNISIA 1996-08-22

A Polish diplomat on Thursday denied a report in a Polish tabloid this week that Libya had refused exit visas to 100 Polish nurses who were trying to return home after working in the North African country.
"That's not true.

To date, we are not aware of any nurse who has been stranded or detained in Libya without her will, and we have not received any complaints," Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, charge d'affaires at the Polish embassy in Tripoli, told Reuters by telephone.

Poland's labour ministry said this week it would send a team to Libya to investigate, but Awdankiewicz said the impetus for the investigation was complaints by some nurses about their working conditions, such as non-payment of wages.
He stated that there are approximately 800 Polish nurses working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iranian exile group based in Iraq pledged Thursday to support Kurdish rebels in Iran after they were attacked by Iranian forces deep inside Iraq last month.

A statement from the Mujahedin-e Khalq movement said its leader Massoud Rajavi met with Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran (KDPI) Secretary General Hassan Rastegar in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed support for Iran's rebel Kurds.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian resistance will continue to stand by its Kurdish compatriots and the resistance movement in Iranian Kurdistan," she said.
A spokesman for the group said the meeting "signals a new level of cooperation between Mujahedin-e Khalq and the Iranian Kurdish opposition".
In July, Iran intensively bombed targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of KDPI guerrillas who are in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside the control of the government in Baghdad.
The Iraqi Kurdish areas bordering Iran are under the control of the Iraqi Kurdish guerrillas of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK).
The PUK and the Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), Iraq's two main Kurdish factions, have controlled northern Iraq since 1991, when Iraqi forces were pushed out of Kuwait during the Gulf War.
Over the weekend, the most serious fighting erupted between the two sides since last year's US-sponsored ceasefire.
Mujahedin Khalq said Iranian forces had also shelled KDP positions in the Qasri area of Suleimaniyah province near the Iranian border over the past two days.
According to her, approximately 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey are launching air and ground attacks on targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of their Kurdish rebels.
US-led air forces in southern Turkey are protecting Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by Baghdad forces.
Saudi riyal exchange rates are stable in quiet summer trading.
The spot Saudi riyal-dollar exchange rate and the riyal interbank deposit rate were mostly stable this week in quiet summer trading, traders in the kingdom said.
"The exchange rates of the Saudi riyal have not changed.
The market was very quiet because of the summer holidays," said one of the sellers.
The spot rate of the riyal was at 3.7504/06 per dollar.
Monthly interbank deposits were at 5-1/2, 3/8%, three-month at 5-5/8, 1/2% and six-month at 5-3/4, 5/8%.
One-year funds were at six, 5-7/8 percent.
Israel approves of Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Israel on Thursday allowed Palestinian President Yasser Arafat to fly over its territory into the West Bank, ending a brief crisis between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, an Arafat adviser said.
"The problem is over.
The president's plane has been cleared to fly through Israeli airspace, but the president is not expected to leave for the West Bank before Monday," Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters.

Arafat was due to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Thursday, but the meeting location was changed to Gaza after Israel refused to allow the Palestinian leader's helicopters to fly over.
Palestinian officials have accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to stop the Ramallah meeting by keeping Arafat on his toes.
Arafat subsequently cancelled a meeting between Israeli and Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) officials on civilian affairs at the Allenby Bridge crossing between Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said Arafat decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday when Israel lifted the ban because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be free until Monday.
Arafat meets Peres in Gaza after the flight ban.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday after Palestinians said the right-wing Israeli government barred the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank for talks with the former prime minister.

Japanese Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said at a press conference on Wednesday that in his view, the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) interest rate policy, which is aimed at ensuring economic growth, has not changed following the release of the central bank's "tankan" survey.
